Reviews.Title: Fantastic upgrade to those 35mm film disposable underwater cameras!
Reviews.Author: Kara
Reviews.Content: Just got this camera, and so far find it to be a fantastic value. I was drawn to this camera by it's price and megapixel size (of up to 8.1). This price I got it for is very competitive with similar cameras of lower 3-6 megapixel ranges (I snagged it for about ninety dollars).But please do keep an eye on the prices because I've seen the price on this change very frequently (in a matter of minutes) and vary about $15, since I started writing this review.Why else did I get it? I'm going on a trip to the Bahamas in August and don't want to take 35mm underwater disposable cameras with me. Airport X-ray machines can ruin the film if it's in your carry on (since most of those cameras use ISO 800 film) and that's the only luggage I plan on bringing. So I wanted to take a digital camera since I'll be snorkeling while I'm down there, as well as have it not get ruined if it fell off a kayak or it started to rain. I'm too terrified to try one of those underwater pouches for my primary camera (a Samsung S700) due to lack of reviews on the pouch-type it would require and fear that if it got ruined I'd be out my favorite camera so I've opted for this camera and so far I am SO glad I did! Vivitar seems to have fit a lot of nice features into this point & shoot camera.But if you're looking for a professional camera, let me stop you right now and tell you to look elsewhere as this probably won't be anywhere near your expectations. This is by no means considered a professional camera. However, if you're looking for a better option than a 35mm underwater disposable... then it CERTAINLY provides better results than a 35mm film underwater point and shoot camera. I say this with experience from using those 35mm film underwater disaster cameras but from also working in a photo lab where I've seen the vast majority of what those cameras produce at water parks and the Caribbean... and the Vivitar Vivicam 8400 camera is by far so much better.I tested it in my friends pool yesterday and it had no leaks around the gasket/closing mechanism and the pictures were surprisingly clear! I will add some sample photos to the product gallery as soon as I get some I'm willing to share with the public at-large. Overall, I give it a 4 out of 5 and that's because I'm nitpicking.Pro's:- Water resistant up to 30 feet!- Supports an external SD memory card in up to 8GBs in size! This was great for me as I already have plenty of this type of card from my other camera. And this type card is generally inexpensive compared to other size cards. Just to give you an idea of storage capacity I put a 4gb SD card in the camera and it said I could store 1596 pictures at the highest 8.1mp setting OR 1 hour 37 minutes and 15 seconds of video! Obviously, you can do a combination of each if you switch between the modes.- Uses AA size batteries. I've been using energizer rechargeables in this and got a decent amount of life from them from STEADY non-stop use. My suggestion would be to use the photo lithium or the rechargeables as I'm sure that just like all other digital cameras on the market, that they would probably suck the life out of the cheaper basic alkalines.- Reasonably large LCD screen on the camera at 2.4 inches.- Can record photos AND video.- Comes with an adjustable wrist strap so it's easy to secure to your wrist--however, should it come off your wrist the bright yellow color of this camera makes it easy to spot to retrieve unlike the blue model.- Sinks somewhat, so you won't have to deal with too much resistance to keep it staying underwater.- Has the screw hole on the camera's base for mounting to a tripod.- When powering off the camera it clearly displays "Bye-Bye" on the LCD screen.- Easy 1 touch "Mode" button to switch between capturing still photos or video.- Lightning bolt button easily lets you change from auto-flash, flash (for all photos), or no-flash.- Can take photos with Super Fine, Fine, or Normal settings.- Although the camera is 8.1MP, you have the choice of shooting photos in the following resolutions  (8M, 5M, 3M, 2M, 0.3M)-This can be great if you're limited on how much space is on your memory card.- You can adjust the white balance in Still Photo mode OR in Video mode. It defaults to "AWB" (auto white balance) but if you know how you're lighting will affect your photos you can change it between Auto, Day Light, Tungsten, Fluorescent, and Cloudy.- There are 3 Color Effect options to shoot photos in: Color, Sepia and Monochrome.- There's the option of changing the exposure setting from (-2.0 to +2.0): -2.0, -1.5, -1.0, -0.5, Auto, +0.5, +1.0, +1.5, +2.0- It offers a Self Timer of either 10 seconds or 20 seconds.- Date stamp is optional.- A "Burst Snapshot" feature allows you to set up the camera to take 3 continuous images as you move the camera.- Video's are recorded in *.AVI format which are compatible with most Windows type movie-maker programs (ex: Windows Movie Maker, Corel VideoStudio, and many others)- You can change the resolution of the video recording from 640x480 or 320x240. AND change how many frames per second it records (15fps or 30fps)- You can "lock" the pictures you've taken to prevent them from being accidentally deleted.- A Rotate option allows you to rotate photos taken at a 5M resolution or lower, on the camera.- English not your primary language? No problem. There are 7 language options to choose from on the submenu: English, French, German, Italian, Spanish, Portuguese and Chinese.- You can set the light frequency from 50Hz to 60Hz.- The beep/buzzer sound on the camera isn't annoying loud, but you can disable it if you'd like.- Comes with a USB/TV-out cable so that you can play back your photos on the TV or even take photos or video's while hooked up to the TV! Just use the USB cable provided, plug the small end into the camera and then the yellow jack to your yellow jack on your TV, and then turn on the camera! (I've never had this feature before and I think this is awesome!)Con's (and most of these are me nit-picking):- There is a very apparent shutter-lag. The image you THINK you took will freeze on the screen after hitting the shutter for a couple seconds but in actuality it captures your picture about 1-2 seconds later and the actual captured image will flash on the screen for about a 1/2 second.- It does not capture photos well at night or in dark areas.- The locking/closing mechanism on the camera for the area where the SD card and battery compartment is feels a little cheap to me. I think a better material could have been used than plastic clamp/lock. So I would advise closing and opening it with care. You have to push a small black arrow right first to release the long plastic lever, pull that lever all the way down, and then the hinge will release to open the compartment for the batteries, SD card slot, and USB connection.- Buttons on the camera seem a little stiff to press down on, this is probably due to the type of engineering required for this type of cameras purpose.- The Vivitar 8400 is a little larger and heavier than my Samsung S700.- There's no lens cap to protect it when not in use.- No separate "delete" button function. If you want to delete a picture on the camera during playback mode you have to hit the "OK/Menu" button and navigate to the delete option.- After taking a picture, there is very little delay and it disappears very shortly off the LCD screen so there's no time to check it. You have to use the playback mode.- No sound on Video recordings which I think is a bummer given that the lower grade model-though priced higher (seen here: Vivitar VIVICAM-6200W 6.0 MegaPixel Underwater Camera with 4x Digital Zoom 2.0" LCD) had the sound in its video recording option.- No regular viewfinder like on standard cameras so that you don't use up battery power with the live-view LCD screen. And the screen can be somewhat difficult to see underwater.- When switching from auto-flash, flash (for all photos), or no-flash mode using the lightning bolt sometimes it "hangs up" and gets caught switching and the screen will go blank and a blue light beside the screen will flash.- The Rotate option does not allows you to rotate photos taken at the highest 8M resolution, on the camera.- The 61 page user manual is on the CD that comes with the PhoTags software. I realize this is a greener alternative but I would've liked to have had it already pre-printed.- The Photags Express software is not compatible on Macintosh computers.- Does not come with batteries.***UPDATED*** 09/07/2009I just wanted to update you all on my experience with this camera in the Bahamas... and quite frankly, I think it worked out great during all 6 days of snorkeling and swimming! And would still give it 4 stars! NO LEAKS--Even after opening it every night to access the hub in the camera so I could play the pictures and video back on the TV using the video cable that comes with the camera and re-closing it! I used Energizer Lithium AA batteries in it and did not have to change them at all the whole trip. I've added a few pictures from when I went snorkeling to the customer gallery... and one of the great reasons why I still think this was better than a 35mm underwater disposable... I took some great video as well!  (I'll add a compilation of video clips I shot to through a "video review" as soon as I figure out how to). However I did want to make some tips/notes for potential buyers or current users...TIPS & NOTES:DEFINITELY preset the white balance before entering the water or taking ANY pictures! It makes a big difference as to how your pictures and video will turn out. Do not trust the "AWB" aka "Auto White Balance" feature. I found that on sunny days that should be shot under the "daylight" white balance setting would appear blue-ish if you used the AWB setting.YES the screen can be difficult to see underwater, HOWEVER I was able to see the screen enough on a bright sunny day where the water was pretty clear and easily switch between video and picture mode. The cloudier the water is, the harder it was to see in general and of course distinguish what was on the screen--not to mention, when the water is cloudy, you can't expect pristine pictures--that's just silly to expect that.Do not attempt to take pictures of anything less than 3ft in front of you as you are guaranteed to get a blurry/out-of-focus picture. The fixed focus on this camera is just not designed for pictures that close. Take your picture 3ft away for a clear shot and then crop it later. The camera has digital zoom-not optical zoom so you're not going to gain any quality advantage to zooming when taking your picture vs. cropping it later. At least if you don't zoom in, if something moves you have a greater chance of still capturing it.How to play back VIDEO in the playback mode: Once you've found your video clip on the playback screen press the shutter button like you would if you were taking a picture. This will get the video to start playing back on the screen for you. You can hit the shutter button again to stop it.In VIDEO mode: Be sure to hold the camera steady and move it SLOWLY underwater when you're in video mode. Otherwise the video will probably make you feel sick when you play it back later as it will seem like it jumps all over the place.Make sure you rinse the camera well with salt-free tap water after bringing it in the ocean. The salt can crystallize in parts of the camera later making it difficult to close the camera's memory card/battery hatch without risking breaking the hinge. If you close your camera gently and visually inspect the closing latch on the side to make sure it is completely down and the "#1" arrow latch is to the left, so that everything is lined up where it's supposed to be... I don't see why you'd end up with leaks.The pinch clip on the wrist strap to tighten it around your wrist has shown some signs of rusting internally. However, it still works well at tightening.With all that said, if you're looking for a more thorough technical review, I'm sorry--just not an area of my expertise. However the "Technical Specifications" information below is straight out of the user manual and may be of use to you.Image Sensor:5 Mega Pixel CMOS SensorImage Resolution:8M, 5M, 3M, 2M, 0.3MVideo Resolution:VGA 640x480 ,QVGA 320X240 at 30fps or 15fpsMonitor Display:2.4'' TFT LCDCapture:Single, Continuous shotInternal Memory:64MB FlashExternal Memory:SD card up to 8 GBSensitivity:AutoLens:f=7.4mm, F=2.8Shutter Speed:Electronic shutter'1/20 ~ 1/6000 secWhite Balance:Auto, Daylight, Tungsten, Fluorescent, CloudyExposure control:-2EV to +2EV in 0.5 stepPhoto effect:Color/Sepia/MonochromeFlash:Auto, On, OffDigital Zoom:8xSelf-timer:10s/20sFile Format:JPEG, AVITV out:NTSC / PALInterface:USB 1.1PC Camera resolution:640 x 480System Requirements:Windows XP, VISTA or MAC OS9 in Mass Storage modeBattery:2*AA Alkaline batteriesOSD Language:English/French/German/Spanish/Italian/Portuguese/ChineseAuto power off:Disable, 1 min, 3 min, 5 minWorking Temperature:0 to 40° CStorage Temperature:-20 to 60° C

Reviews.Title: Great alternative to disposables
Reviews.Author: Satisfied Buyer
Reviews.Content: Was a little hesitant to purchase after reading some poor reviews but thought I'd give it a shot; I just wanted an inexpensive digital camera I could take to the pool. I took about 30 photos first time out and was able to achieve results good enough to post on my blog. The reason so many reviewers get blurry shots, and the trick to taking good photos with this camera is simple (though a little annoying). There is a very long shutter lag time from when you push the button to when it takes the actual shot. However, and this is the annoying part, there is NO lag time from when you push the shutter button and when the screen freezes the image. So when you push the button the screen freezes immediately although it has yet to take the picture and you must wait for the screen to go back to live motion to know that the picture has been taken. The first couple of pictures I took I would begin to lower the camera just after the screen froze and that would be when it would actually take the picture thus making it blurry shot from my quick hand movement. So when you use this camera and want good results, push the shutter button, the screen will freeze and THEN the shot will be taken and the screen will go back to live motion. Enjoy, it's a good one, just have to get used to the long shutter lag.

Reviews.Title: Leaked water
Reviews.Author: Ray Man
Reviews.Content: Given that the camera leaked water and died on my second day of snorkeling, I consider my 3-star rating to be extra generous.  I've returned the camera for repair/replacement under the terms of the warranty.The photos that I recovered from the 1st day were pretty good...certainly better/more convenient than using a disposable camera.  The video quality is also decent, though there is no sound recording, which is fine for most underwater videography.  Considering the camera's low (tempting) price, the photo & video quality were just about what I expected, if not a little better.  A negative is that it is somewhat difficult to use underwater: the view screen is hard to see, and the image of the photo you just took remains on the view screen for barely a second.  On land, I found some of the functions non-intuitive (such as reviewing and deleting images), and the camera sometimes "froze," requiring me to turn it off and on again to reset.Overall, I find the ViviCam 8400 serves as a relatively inexpensive, moderate upgrade to disposable cameras.  If it hadn't leaked water and died on me, I might have even give it 4 stars given the low price.  I'll be interested to see if other reviewers experience issues with water leakage.UPDATE (March 2011):  My rating has steadily dropped.  It was a huge hassle to get a replacement camera from Vivitar.  First, they sent me an incredibly cheap NON-waterproof camera (total junk).  After much pestering, I finally received a replacement.  Looking past the fact that the camera leaked water, I'm surprised I was so kind in my original review of photo quality.  Don't be fooled by the 8 MP specs; photos look more like they are taken with an old-school 1 MP camera and are often blurry.  And that's on land!  I thought I might have bought a lemon originally, but the replacement has the same problems, often freezing up...very frustrating and annoying.  My new recommendation: if you want a toy for your kids, this might suffice.  But if you're hoping to take nice vacation photos, look elsewhere and be willing to spend a little more.  I'm looking into Intova products, which seem to combine quality at a good price.

Reviews.Title: Important Information
Reviews.Author: Jeremy Davis
Reviews.Content: Ok so I read alot of review and I bought this camera and there are basically 3 important things you need to know.-The First is that this is a camera that goes under water.  you have to take care of the seal.  I work on multi million dollar sub for a living and the one thing that is always true with anything that goes under water it's that it needs a greased seal.  No matter how good your O-Ring you need to keep it from being Dry. This camera has 2 major seals that  you have to take out and grease up.  I recommend Dow 111 Silicon gel  it's available for $16 and comes in a tube that will last for about 1-5 years of use. compared with the cost of a new camera thats dirt cheap.  Alternatively you can use Vaseline or most any marine grease.So you will want to open up the the data port on the side and remove the seal in there and set it aside.  You will want to remove the the door that held the seal to get at the other seal.  Simply push the hinge pin up and out of the door and set the pin and door aside.  This can be done with a jewlers screw driver or a metal coat hanger.  Now remove the 8 screws on the back of the camera and lift the back off of the camera.  Now just remove the seal you find in this cover.With the 2 seals out all you need to do is smear a thin film onto the seals and reassemble.  you want a wet look but no clumping.  You will want to repeat this with the small in the data door before ever dive, but the lager seal won't need clean and re-greased more them once every 6 months or so.With that don't you should be leak free as long as you own the camera.--Second you have to let it air our.  This one is simple but you won't think of it on you own.  When you put the camera away after a dive leave the camera open.---Third and this one is my only complaint.  This camera has a fixed focal length.  That means that you have to be about 4 feet away from what ever you want to take a picture of, or it will be out of focus.

Reviews.Title: Couldn't be worse!
Reviews.Author: LLPD "LLPD"
Reviews.Content: Please note that this is the same as the yellow Vivitar 8400, and see that the one-star reviews dominate.  I saw the bad reviews, but I gambled and bought this horrible camera.  What a joke.  We never even got to use it, because after turning it on the screen would go grey after only a few minutes and it would freeze up - couldn't even turn it off.  This camera wasn't a lot of money, but we wound up on our tropical vacation with no underwater camera!  Please be smarter than me, and notice that the most common ratings for this camera are for only one star.  Sure a few people got one that seemed to work, but most people did not, so odds are you won't either!  Don't waste your time and money, and don't risk the frustration of not getting what you need for your vacation.

Reviews.Title: Designed to Flood
Reviews.Author: Bob Ross
Reviews.Content: I can't comment on the quality of the pictures from this camera as I don't have any yet, and may never if the SD chip was ruined..On the camera's third trip into the water I noticed water in the view screen area.  Then I noticed that the battery/SD card compartment door was not properly seated.  I have diagnosed the underlying problem as poor design with respect to the battery compartment door locking mechanism.  There is a single release button which stands proud of the surrounding surface.  If it is bumped or brushes up against your wrist it can easily release the locking lever on the battery compartment door.  The locking lever is spring-loaded to pop up into a position where it is easy to manipulate to complete opening the battery compartment door.  But it appears that, even with the locking lever only partially raised, the watertight seal will have been broken allowing water to enter the camera.A good solution might be to have two relase buttons rather than one and for both to be recessed so that they are not easy to release accidently.  The locking lever should also be redesigned so that it does not automatically pop up into a semi-opened condition.If you already have one of these cameras and have not flooded it, I suggest that you try electrical tape over the release button and the locking lever as a way to prevent accidental opening.  If Vivitar replaces mine (it goes in the mail tomorrow), that is what I am going to try.

Reviews.Title: Leaks within 10 minutes of water entry
Reviews.Author: Gary Droubay
Reviews.Content: Very unhappy with this camera.  Went snorkling with this camera on Oahu North Shore.  It leaked within 10 minutes of entering the water.  Bottom line we were snorkling, it leaked at a depth of about 2 feet.  Batteries reacted with water and destroyed the sd card.  I returned to the beach and a couple from Texas asked if the camera leaked--I said yes and they said they had the same problem--Their camera leaked within 10 minutes of entering the water.Do not waste your money.  Only useful as a traditional digital camera--DO NOT GO SWIMMING WITH IT.

Reviews.Title: Expensive digital disposable
Reviews.Author: McBud
Reviews.Content: We were looking for a digital answer to the expensive underwater disposables and this looked to be the answer. It is not.  We purchased this camera after seeing good reviews and understood that your $100 only gets you so much.  The camera was ordered 2 weeks before a two week vacation in the Bahamas.  First dive ... approx 100 nice quality pictures and even good video quality. Noticed some dampness on USB hook-up to the laptop but nothing severe.  Second dive ... 15 pictures and the camera is dead.  Pulled the card to save the picures and the LCD screen and camera/memory card compartment is soaking wet. ... Dead camera. Returned from vacation just as the 30 day product return policy kicked.  Final evaluation: About 100 nice pictures for $100.  Don't buy it.  Spend the money and get something better.

Reviews.Title: Unsatisfactory picture quality
Reviews.Author: Hollis Hanover
Reviews.Content: This camera has a good price, great appearance, good waterproof integrity and takes absolutely crummy pictures.  It seems as if the shutter stays open long enough that after you snap and the image freezes in the viewscreen the subject can move and blur the final image.  I tried all the settings, made sure I had strong batteries and got the same result.  This baby's going back to Walmart.Hollis

Reviews.Title: COMPLETE WASTE OF MONEY!
Reviews.Author: R. A. Englehart
Reviews.Content: I got this camera for shallow water scuba diving (max 30 feet) and at first I thought I had found a great buy.  BOY was I WRONG!  I've taken this camera out only 5 times, and yesterday, water leaked into the camera and destroyed it.  Not to mention, when it DID work, it had such a long delay that I could never get a shot of anything moving!  I only gave it 1 star because I wasnt able to give it ZERO!Vivitar, you should be ashamed of your horrible product.DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY ON THIS CAMERA!!

Reviews.Title: Self-destructed on second dive
Reviews.Author: Caribsnorkler
Reviews.Content: This camera worked on one dive, taking fair pictures as long as the zoom was not used.  On the second dive, snorkeling on the surface, it filled with water and was ruined.  I can not recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: Affordable Underwater Camera (point and shoot)
Reviews.Author: E. Estrada "Single Dad of 4"
Reviews.Content: My daughter wanted a waterproof camera to take to the pool and to girls camp.  Works great as a point and shoot.It does not have a optical zoom; told my daughter to set the camera at 8MP on auto mode, leave it there and edit pics on computer later. Camera has worked flawlessly.My daughter used it for a week at camp and today we went to the pool. Took pictures both underwater and on the water. Uses 2 AA batteries which seem to last quite well.The Camera is a bit bulky (a deterant to stealing) and there is very noticable lag on the shutter.  But for the price, its hard to complain.SD card slot is behind waterproof door next to battery compartment/cover. Either the batteries need to be removed to remove/install SD card or you have to use a key to push SD Card past the lock/unlock spring. We installed a class 6, 4GB high speed SD Card.Camera comes with a wrist band with a locking slide to keep camera from being pulled away or dropped. Camera is almost neutral bounancy and sinks slowly (in pool), and highly recommend installing and using wrist strap especially in the ocean where tide/waves can pull camera away.If you close the waterproof door correctly, I cannot see any reason why the camera would leak.The camera has a narrow focal angle, so you will have to back up if you want to take a pic of a group (see posted pics). Other than the bulkiness, shutter lag, and narrow focal distance, the camera is just what my daughter wanted; simple to use point and shoot that is waterproof!

Reviews.Title: Not a Divers underwater camera... but great for kids and out-doorsy types!
Reviews.Author: Kay Wilson
Reviews.Content: If you need a small, light weight, travel camera that is water / beach / gentle shock resistant then this is the perfect camera. It is compact, light, and water resistant to 3m / 15ft. Ideal for snorkelers.Should you be planning to undertake underwater photography you will find this camera very limiting. It's very small lens and teeny flash are just not up to it!Great little camera for the price, and perfect as a childs first digital camera, as its robust, and not as delicate as most digital point and shoots in the entry level class.

Reviews.Title: Vivitar Vivicam 8400 Great Underwater Camera
Reviews.Author: Leo Dillon
Reviews.Content: Recently went on a Cruise to the West Caribbean, the camera worked great for both land and underwater. The photoswere clear and crisp along with the video. I had added a larger memory card and used ALK Batteries, the camera lasted without having to change the batteries. This camera is very water tight, I scuba dived to 40ft with no leaks to the camera. The only problem I had with this camera, it is hard to see the view finder underwater, I had to just point and shoot. Overall I give this camera a Vivitar ViviCam 8400 8.1 MP 2.4-Inch TFT LCD Screen Underwater Digital Camerahigh rating.

Reviews.Title: Best buy for your money!
Reviews.Author: Maria
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera to go snorkling in Cozumel with. I just got back from my trip and it took such good photos. Also it takes the SDHC card which is nice. I was able to take an 11 minute video. The buttons are easy to use and simple. I'm so glad I got this camera instead of disposables. There is no view finder but i was still about to get great pictures. Plus if you are taking pictures of fish, its not like the stand still. I did take the batteries and card out after i was done in the water to dry out (just in case). Hope this helps!

Reviews.Title: Big Mistake
Reviews.Author: Jose M.M.
Reviews.Content: I saw this in amazon and figured this was the way to go. How could you loose? So I purchased 2 of them thinking it would be a great toy to have when we go swimming and do any water sport with our kids. Well beside the 1-2 second delay in snapping the picture(giving you a blurry photo), the camera sucks the life out of your batteries in a matter of minutes (10min.). I have used good alkaline name brands Ener. & Dura. They only seem to last for a few minutes once the camera is turned on. Amazingly high energy consumption! I am returning them since I figured both of them are in the same condition. I just wont chance opening the second one. Better to just return them both and look for something better.

Reviews.Title: Terrible camera.
Reviews.Author: J. Paulsonn
Reviews.Content: I can't believe they're still selling this outdated piece of junk.  I made the big mistake of buying one several years ago, and I will admit 1) it did take pictures, and 2) it did not leak.Other than that, I have nothing good to say about it.  The controls on the Vivitar are completely different from any other digital camera--and I've owned at least a dozen different digital cameras over the years.  The controls are baffling: multiple pushes of cryptically-labelled pushbuttons are required, and, over time, the pushbuttons start to stick in the "in" position.  Then what are you supposed to do?  Pull them out with tweezers?  While you're swimming?I would say look around here on Amazon and buy just about ANY other underwater camera that you can find.  There are new ones now that work great, are easier to use and take better pictures.  If you can find one in a yard sale for five bucks, buy it and give it to the kids.  If they can figure it out.

Reviews.Title: Great Hobby Camera for the Price
Reviews.Author: Eric F. Mejia
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera for its intended market, i.e., a hobbyist.  I bought this camera to take on a trip to Hawaii where I planned on snorkeling.  The deciding factors were the price, depth rating, and video feature.  I read the Amazon reviews, and following the advice of some of the more knowledgeable reviewers I inspected and silicon lubed both O-rings to ensure a positive seal.  I used a lithium battery to ensure long battery life.  Finally, I carefully reviewed how to shut the battery door (it's best to download the full manual on line).  I went snorkeling three times, and the camera was in the water fully immersed for several hours at a time.  There were no leaks, the battery lasted all week, and both pictures and videos came out great.  Some minor contrast and lighting adjustments help them "pop".  It's not a pro camera, like a Sealife, but then again it doesn't cost $100s. Overall, I'm very satisfied with its performance.  I'll try to post a few pictures taken at Hanauma Bay to accompany the review

Reviews.Title: Understand what you are buying
Reviews.Author: Bill in SoDak
Reviews.Content: I'm a PADI certified diver and I bought this camera to use when I go scuba diving.  I got it at a clearance price of around $50.  I've had it around a year and so far it's worked good.  Before you consider the quality of the photos to be junk understand how underwater photography works.  Things are a LOT different and light changes a lot under water.  In a swimming pool not as much but in open water (lakes, oceans, rivers) water is not as clear.  The first color you lose as you go deeper is red.  This affects your photos and is NOT the camera's fault.  The high end cameras use special filters and color correction programs to fix this issue.  Also the high end cameras have the strobe (flash) off to the side at a 45 degree angle which is the best for underwater (you ALWAYS use a flash underwater even on sunny days to help with colors and photo quality etc).  This camera has the flash right above the lens which is not ideal.  This is a good camera for a great price.  Like anything else, you get what you pay for.  If you want photos with quality good enough for National Geographic then this is not the camera for you.  Most of the water leaking issues can be prevented by inspecting, cleaning and lubricating the O-ring seal.  Even though it's only rated to 30 feet I've taken it routinely to around 45 ft with no problems.  Had I paid $600 then I would be very disapponted with the functions and photo quality but considering it's low cost, it's well worth it.  Disposible cameras are around $12 and then you have to pay developing fees.  So even if you only use this camera a few times you break even.  Considering water proof housings for non-waterproof cameras are between $150-$200 this is a great deal.  I would buy another one even if this one wears out at some point.

Reviews.Title: Didn't work from the minute we got it out of the box...
Reviews.Author: SwimMomWV
Reviews.Content: I got this camera for my daughter. We have many other digital cameras and are comfortable in the initial setup. However, on this camera, no matter what we tried (including going step by step from the manual) we could not get this camera to work. We tried 2 sets of new batteries.Additionally, I was not happy with the construction of this camera even if it did work. It was difficult to open and was not going to be something that my 12 year old daughter could manage with ease.Stay away. Buck up the extra $50 and get something good.

Reviews.Title: good camera
Reviews.Author: porschelyne
Reviews.Content: I have dove with this camera several times took it too 113 feet did not leak... the trick to the camera is closing it correctly.. you have to squeeze it shut before putting lever down.. The camera is negative Boycey so use a float..

Reviews.Title: Great alternative to disposable cameras
Reviews.Author: S. Clark
Reviews.Content: Bought this camera to go on a cruise.  Was nervous based on a couple negative reviews but decided I'd try it since results with disposable cameras were less than desirable pics in past.It was a good choice!  Camera did not leak, SD card and batteries stayed dry.  Picture quality was surprisingly good.  It holds upto a 8gb card so I just kept on taking pictures.  The advantage of deleting bad pics is great, can't do that with a disposable.It does have a flash but pics in low light did not come out well (we went cave tubing in Belize- in caves pics no good, but outside of caves the pictures were very good).Agree with other reviews, the screen is hard to see at times and there is no peep hole.  But if you are used to pointing and clicking, you'll get your picture.Also, it is slow to take pictures.  But I didn't find it interfering in taking pics.I would advise anyone on the fence about this camera to give it a try....I'm glad I did.  By the time you buy a couple disposable cameras and develop the film (in which maybe half you pics come out decent) you could have bought this camera (which you will have to keep and keep using).

Reviews.Title: Not a Pro Cam but good for the price.
Reviews.Author: D. Spencer "My Life is based on a True Story."
Reviews.Content: This camera looks like a Fisher Price toy.I bought this cam with the intent on doing an underwater photo session in a pool with a model. I was going to slave fire my studio lights off the small built in flash. Then I was going to edit the photos in the computer and create Beautiful Mermaid images from the photos captured with this camera.The session NEVER happened because the camera never showed up!It was lost in shipping.I missed the photo session by 14 days.The GOOD thing is that Amazon made it "right" and sent out another camera NEXT DAY.I got it the next day and played with it a bit. I'm not impressed with the LOOKS or STYLE.The BIGGEST issue with this camera is the SLOW SHUTTER LAG.You MUST hold the camera still even AFTER snapping the shutter.If you do that, then the photos are nice and sharp.Video is nice also (not GREAT... just nice)but what do you expect for under $100.00?I have yet to see what this camera can "really" do underwater. I will use a tripod in the pool for this just because the shutter lag. I will upload the results of our first session (If this site lets me edit this review).Overall, I'd get it again for the price.

Reviews.Title: Small Price, but it does the job.
Reviews.Author: J. Mingoia
Reviews.Content: Just to it on a vacation to Mexico. went snorkeling and the  under water videos  and photos were pretty good. Above water not so good!I only payed 90 bucks with tax and it was worth it.

Reviews.Title: Terrible picture
Reviews.Author: HoGall
Reviews.Content: Don't waste your money on this camera; unless you want a bunch of blurry pictures.  The picture's quality is worst than my cell (3.1MEGA)

Reviews.Title: POOR!!!
Reviews.Author: Thomas J. Dyer "COOP-D"
Reviews.Content: The camers looks like it was made by Fisher Price... Plastic, the locking door is plastic... It took OK pictures out of the water but I tried it under water (1 or 2 feet) and it got water in the lens. Every picture after that was cloudy!!!  If you want a good under water camera pay the extra money... "You get what you pay for!"

Reviews.Title: Nice Camera, but the Wrist Strap Sucks
Reviews.Author: Emory carrigan "Rockin' M"
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera for a trip to the Riviera Maya area of Mexico.  It worked great although I wish the camera floated.  I had a 35mm underwater camera that floated.  Anyway, the wrist strap had one of those pinch type plastic buckles to connect the camera to the wrist strap and that buckle broke during a ride on a wave runner, the camera sunk and was lost.  If the buckle was better, or it floated I will still have this camera.

Reviews.Title: POS Camera leaked on third use
Reviews.Author: Angela J Adams
Reviews.Content: The first two times I tried to use the camera the pictures came out fuzzy and unuseable.  I attibuted it to user error, as I tried to learn a new camera.  The third time water filled the screen on the back.  By the time I snorkeled back to shore, I had ruined my new rechargeable batteries, my memory card, and the POS camera.I have now lost $90 and not gotten a single useable picture.  Of course the return date ended a week ago, so now I am just out of luck.

Reviews.Title: Not for diving
Reviews.Author: Fekus
Reviews.Content: It goes deep till 30 M but the photo quality is really bad, colors is not at all god ... You might use it in a pool however I wonder why you pay even a dollar in something that gives such poor photo quality. I regret buying it and wish I could send it back but don't know how.

Reviews.Title: sent it back
Reviews.Author: jamie whitley
Reviews.Content: the picture quality was very poor and camera was pretty bulky. i wouldnt recommend this camera but i do like the thought of a water proof digital camera.

Reviews.Title: Do Not Buy This
Reviews.Author: Neckman
Reviews.Content: I finally had to throw it away when the port the cable hooks into disappeared into the camera.  Same thing happened to the one this replaced.  Find a different camera.

Reviews.Title: leaked
Reviews.Author: joel l. koon jr
Reviews.Content: I've owned the camera for about a year and you have to be super careful loading the batteries and the sd card when closing this cover up. It's not easy to tell if the cover is sealed or not. Last weekend while taking pictures kiteboarding, the cover appeared to be closed, but after it failed to function, I did a closer inspection and found that it was not quite as closed as I thought.  If you buy this camera, keep this in mind.

Reviews.Title: Leaked, very disappointed
Reviews.Author: Violet "Mothership"
Reviews.Content: Took it snorkeling in St Maarten and right way (even after closing it properly as in the directions) the lens fogged up. When we got back to the ship I opened it up to let it "dry" out. When I put the batteries back in after 3 days it would not operate. Only good thing about this was the lens was great for still pictures above water I took when trying to learn the camera features. It did not serve its purpose, very sad. Company that shipped it was GREAT fast service and easy returns. I"ll buy again from them.

Reviews.Title: Disposable verses Digital
Reviews.Author: Jamie L. Owen
Reviews.Content: I bought this Camera because I have been vacationing a lot and was tired of buying the Disposable underwater cameras. This camera was a reasonable enough price that if I didn't like it I wouldn't be to mad on what I spent. I LOVED IT! I had it for a week in Costa Rica. Every day we would start our day in the ocean, then hung out at the pool in the afternoon. It was great to take photo's above water but hanging by water. I had no worries about people dropping it in. We did Tubing, Hot Spring Bath, and when it rained I didn't worry either. All the photos came out awesome! Some photos were a little blurry from fog on the lenses. I would wipe it and it would be fine. The downfall to this camera is you need a steady hand. Yet if camera was wet it didn't really matter how steady your hand was. It has no zoom. The Flash takes forever to take a photo and by the time it took, the person or animal would have moved so it made a blurry photo. So if you buy this, bring a land camera for your land activities and use this just for water stuff. Over-all I would recommend this to anyone. WAY BETTER THEN DISPOSABLES.

Reviews.Title: No more Disposable Underwater Cameras Needed
Reviews.Author: S. Gingerich "Steve"
Reviews.Content: Ok, let's first start off that this is no where near a professional camera, nor is it one for any type of photography enthusiast.  But if you want to get some pictures with your kids and the family without worrying about your nice dryland camera and not deal with those cheap disposables that limit you on how many pictures you can take, and then you have to get developed before you know you have maybe 3-4 good pictures, then this camera might be for you.I purchased this camera for your my wife who is avid scrapbooker.  Even though she would purchase them on sale, she was constantly getting disposable underwater cameras, that she would then have to get developed.  This was the perfect alternative.Pros.  The best things about this camera are in its' name.  Its an 8 Megapixel underwater camera.  Supporting SDHC, so you can fit a great deal of pics on to one card.  It seems to be good on battery life******ASSUMING***** you use the right batteries. In any digital camera or device we use, we use the Energizer rechargables, and get great life.  And with their 15 minute recharger, you are rarely out of service for long.  Although in a pinch, it's nice that you can pick up any AA batteries to use.  But I'm sure it would eat through normal alkalines in a heartbeat.Cons.  There are a couple little caveats that you have to deal with.  This camera is SLOW to take pictures, so it is best for set up shots.  And sometimes that can cause a bit of distortion with your images.  But as long as you don't move until the image in the viewfinder flickers and is back to showing everything live, you will be fine.After reading another review, they were absolutely right about the White balance.  Don't use the Auto, if you set the white balance, your pictures will come out so much better, yes that makes it a bit less of a point and shoot, but in the end it's a small price to pay.Overall, it's a nice little camera for the price.  Especially for the weekend scrap booker or the family memory maker.  No you won't be doing a professional photo shoot with it, but you will probably pay for itself in a couple trips to the water.  If you count the cost of the disposable cameras and development versus the amount of good pictures you get.  Yes all your images won't come out, but its' digital take a bunch, you are bound to get enough that you would really like to print.

Reviews.Title: Couldn't be worse!
Reviews.Author: LLPD "LLPD"
Reviews.Content: I saw the bad reviews, but there was that really great long detailed review at the top, so I bought this horrible camera.  What a joke.  We never even got to use it, because after turning it on the screen would go grey and it would freeze up - couldn't even turn it off.  This camera wasn't a lot of money, but we wound up on our tropical vacation with no underwater camera!  Please be smarter than me, and notice that the most common ratings for this camera are for only one star.  Sure a few people got one that seemed to work, but most people did not!  Don't waste your time and money, and don't risk the frustration of not getting what you need for your vacation.

Reviews.Title: Water leaked after second day of use
Reviews.Author: D. Roberts
Reviews.Content: The first day I used this camera out snorkeling, it was very easy to use for taking photos and video.  The pictures turned out OK, definitely better than the underwater disposable cameras I used during snorkeling.  The video quality was choppy, small and mediocre.But during the second use of this camera, the water leaked into it!  The end door does not seal very well.  I noticed another reviewer had the same problem too.

Reviews.Title: camera
Reviews.Author: Bill Harper
Reviews.Content: I received the camera in good time . I like it but I am disappointed in the quality of pictures it takes .

Reviews.Title: I don't know WHAT you bad reviewers are TALKING about!!!!
Reviews.Author: Matthew J. Vanessen
Reviews.Content: I don't know what those of you who have given this a bad review are talking about! I LOve this camera. We just took it to the beach and had hours of fun! It lags a little before you take the shot, but once you know that you can adjust to it! It is super easy to use and the picture quality is excellent!The only negative I have is when you zoom in all the way, sometimes it does not focus on far away things as well, but that is a minor inconvenience.

Reviews.Title: Good All Around Camera
Reviews.Author: Officer 777
Reviews.Content: Product is a good camera for any type of environment.Fits well in travel case and/or purse.  Doesn't takethe highest quality picture, but, good for the typeof camera.  The product was delivered on time and ingood condition.

Reviews.Title: Not worth any amount of Money
Reviews.Author: dande2169
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for a vacation my husband and I took to Hawaii. I had done a lot of research and this camera had great reviews and wasn't very expensive. However, once we took the camera into the water (a pool, actually), we got 10 pictures snapped off before the camera broke. The case leaked and water got into it. It even ruined our memory card. So, we couldn't get the pictures off of it - I never got to see how they turned out. It was a complete waste of money and cost me more in the end (replacing the memory card). I suspect, I would have had better luck with a disposable waterproof camera. I would never recommend this camera to anyone!

Reviews.Title: It is a good camera for the price
Reviews.Author: Holly Gioannini
Reviews.Content: I didn't get alot of chances to use it, but when I did, it performed like it said it would.  The only complaint I have is that it takes to long to take the actual picture and it was difficult to tell when it actually did take the picture.  When I looked back at the photos, everything turned out nice and clear.

Reviews.Title: Great Product
Reviews.Author: georgia_pk
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for a snorkeling trip.  It worked great!  I was able to take some really great underwater pictures.

Reviews.Title: OK camera for price but works for underwater quite well!
Reviews.Author: Kristen S. Smith
Reviews.Content: -can't really see what you're doing under-water so I just snapped at random things and hoped for the best.  The case is solid, if you close it properly and move sand and gunk out of the seams it works flawlessly.  My pictures from the grand cayman came out great!!!  I did use it out of the water as well and had trouble seeing the photo and screen was kind of blurry but it did it's job and i'll use it again.

Reviews.Title: Decent camera
Reviews.Author: C. Schumacher
Reviews.Content: The back screen doesn't really do the picture justice, but when I pulled the pictures off the camera, they looked really good. I was surprised.

Reviews.Title: Cheap...and NOT really good underwater!
Reviews.Author: Lawrence Gutter "LarrytheComputerGuy"
Reviews.Content: So I didn't want to get a "good" camera for underwater use on Galapagos trip, and, I DIDN'T!!  Body molding does not inspire confidence when I removed from blister-pack packaging, but didn't leak water at all.  Photos taken, though, were extremely disappointing underwater--sort of "point and pray" when shooting fish, seals, turtles, etc.  Got only a few barely usable shots!  Using while  cruising coast in Zodiac rubber boat did produce some decent above water shots of coastal rocks and blue-footed boobies. Flash ineffective underwater.Save your money and buy postcards...totally useless for intended purpose.  Someone suggested giving to kids...just don't let them expect to get good underwater shots!  Very disappointed!

Reviews.Title: good pics
Reviews.Author: mz helena
Reviews.Content: this takes good pics and its perfect for me to take to the beach, kayaking ect... I got it on clearance for 29 dollars so im pretty happy with the price. the pics really arent bad and its easy to use. dont like the fact that it uses batteries and does not charge like newer cameras.

Reviews.Title: You get what you pay for...
Reviews.Author: Deanna Owens
Reviews.Content: Purchased this for a cruise that included some underwater shore excursions.  Really could not see the screen under water, had to guess at what you were getting when you took a picture.  I was very disappointed in this camera.  It did work, it was waterproof.  But you have no idea whether or not you're getting a picture because you can't see the screen!  I didn't think it was working so stopped using it.  My iPhone with a waterproof cover worked better.Next time I'll spend more money and get a useful camera.

Reviews.Title: LCD Screen difficult to see
Reviews.Author: philmsherman
Reviews.Content: The camera takes good pictures when everything is just right, but it is difficult to see how they are turning out because the LCD Screen is so dark. When taking a picture, it is very hard to tell when it it takes so you just keep snapping. It may get better after I have used it more. I bought it for snorkeling and just for taking to the beach or on the water when I don't want to risk my more expensive camera that is not waterproof.

Reviews.Title: You get what you pay for...
Reviews.Author: K. Wood
Reviews.Content: True to what the other reviews say. The screen is too dark and its hard to see the pic you've taken or if the camera is even on at times. It's kind of like having a camera in the 80's, you take the picture and have no idea what it looks like until you're in a darker room to see the screen, but when that happens, if you get the image you wanted you won't be disappointed. It does take a good quality picture.

Reviews.Title: Slow, freezes sometimes
Reviews.Author: Dave
Reviews.Content: I picked this up for $65 on Amazon where I see the price is steadily dropping on this model that's been out for a few years.  The delay in snapping the picture is definitely annoying, so you have to be sure to hold it still until you see the picture actually show up on the LCD.  Be sure you have a clear, good mask or goggles because it can be hard to see the LCD screen underwater.  Sometimes the screen goes black and a blue light comes on, which I presume to mean "standby".  Shooting video is hit or miss.  Sometimes when going into video mode, the camera outright freezes and you have to get somewhere dry, open the battery compartment and close it again to reset the power.The videos are AVI format, which is fine but I'd prefer MOV.I'd have been really annoyed paying $200 for this or even over $100.  For $65 I'll give it to my kids to play with for still shots in the pool and seek out something of better quality (and more $$$).  Unlike other reviews, mine hasn't started leaking (yet).

Reviews.Title: One drop and dead.
Reviews.Author: Dad
Reviews.Content: Bought this product for my son.  He loved it (he was 9, and it was big and yellow) however for the price, the quality was not there.  The image quality is poor.  Get better pics from the old 3MP camera I just used at the Grand Canyon.  The video is even worse (No sound).  It was at least water resistant since my Son's were able to play with it in the pool.  We did not try actually going under the water with it however.  I new the above about the camera from reading other reviews.  The thing about this camera that burns me is that I purchased it because is is ruggedized.  It should be a good camera for  a preteen boy.  surprisingly my son was always very gentle with it.  My other son however managed to drop it on the floor while watching a video.  Now we get nothing (ONE DROP).  So for a camera that is built to be tough, It couldn't hold up to a drop of less than 3 feet.  The funny thing is that I witnessed a gentleman drop his 12MP camera with the extra lenses on the rocks at the Grand Canyon this weekend.  He picked it up, put the battery cover back on and all still worked.  I see now I can purchase a replacement for my son's camera for $67.  Still not cheap enough for all the bad!!!!! wrong with this camera.

Reviews.Title: I liked it!
Reviews.Author: Makobleiu
Reviews.Content: I owned this camera for several years.  I bought it used for $60, but I have heard that it is possible to get it cheaper nowadays if you shop around.Pro's:User-friendly and easy to learn.  Very waterproof if you are careful about the seals (i.e., make sure to lock battery case tightly, keep hair/dirt off o-rings, etc.)  Takes good pictures and waterproof seals were very reliable. Another GREAT pro: it's waterproof to 60ft, which is unusual in the market of cheaper waterproof cameras.  Most go to either 10 or 30 ft, but this is a better dive camera because of it's depth capabilities.Con's:It's heavy.  An antiquated "brick" style, it's bulky and there seem to be better, lighter cameras out there these days for a similar price.  (However, like an old cell phone from the 90's, it may be bulky but it sure was reliable!) Another con is that it does not have a very efficient "automatic" setting for UW shots.  You need to get into the water and manually program the white balance according to the amount of sunlight in the water before proceeding with your snorkel trip or dive. Finally, thing thing sucks battery life like a camel at a watering hole with a big straw.  You will need spare batteries for a 2-dive trip.Overall, I really liked this camera.  It's now an old model, but I found it to be a good camera for its era and very affordable for what you get.  Mine finally died due to unfortunate user error (I tried to change out the batteries early in the morning before a dive and BEFORE COFFEE, and did not fully seal the battery compartment, which of course caused the camera to leak. It was my fault and mine alone).  Hope this review helps with your purchasing decisions!

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera
Reviews.Author: Barbara  RN
Reviews.Content: I have owned numerous underwater cameras over the years and found this camera incredible, considering it's low cost. Just came back for a month sail in the Caribbean and want to state that I am amazed at the high quality still pictures that this camera took while snorkeling. I used the camera underwater about 15-20 times and had absolutely no problem with leakage. Like any underwater camera or enclosure, it is necessary to be sure the camera is properly closed and also that there is no dirt, sand or lint on the rubber seal. Fantastic little camera. By the way, I did take somemovies with the camera and though they are interesting to look at, the resolution was not as good as the still pictures. They seem to be a bit on the grainy side.All in all I am extremely pleased with this camera, especially considering it's price. Highly recommend it! Reviewed by-CaptainPJ

Reviews.Title: Totally worthless JUNK
Reviews.Author: Ripped Off
Reviews.Content: I bought the Vivitar Vivicam 8400 to take on vacation, to use as a general camera and an underwater camera.  The LCD screen is so dim that it cannot be seen at all in any kind of sunlight including under water.  the fact that the camera does not have a view finder other than LCD screen means you can't use it at all outdoors. The only time you can see the LCD screen at all is in very deep shade or indoors in a dimly lit room.  DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY ON THIS PIECE OF JUNK!

Reviews.Title: vivitar underwater camera
Reviews.Author: maggie
Reviews.Content: This is my second purchase - I already have a similar camera which is fantastic - which I have used daily in all weathers- over and under water - and the photos from it are great - as a result I treated myself to this purchase for Christmas.  I put my photos up on facebook so the proof is there.

Reviews.Title: Sadly disappointed
Reviews.Author: MisterG
Reviews.Content: Was thrilled to receive my Vivitar camera and try out the underwater capabilities. Sadly, on my first underwater test the camera snapped 2 photos andvthen stopped working. The camera was submerged for less than five minutes and in less than 6 inches of water. I managed to get the 2 pics off the memiry card which came out great but in the end the camera was returned.

Reviews.Title: Vivitar Service is Outstanding
Reviews.Author: Donna Raymond
Reviews.Content: I purchased aVivitar underwater camera right when they came out.  It stopped working after the first dive.  I sent it in to Vivitar but since I no longer had a receipt, didn't expect anything.  Low and behold, I received a NEW and much improved Vivitar 8400 by return mail.  It worked great through many snorkel dives over the next 2 years.  Then I neglected to close the camera properly and ruined it.  The reason I'm on this site is that I am going to buy another one.  The only real complaint I have is the fish are hard to see in the LCD screen.  They are hard enough to photo without the complication of point and hope.

Reviews.Title: Leaked
Reviews.Author: Neil A. Mowery "macman"
Reviews.Content: This camera was purchased for a college project that caused me to have to buy another brand of camera because this one leaked very badly!

Reviews.Title: Excelent Choice...
Reviews.Author: Chris R "Life is a game, Play it!"
Reviews.Content: I'll do this simple...  Get it!  Think of all the times you went to the pool or beach with friends and you didnt want to bring your camera for fear of it getting wet.  Simple to use, and sturdy to give confort in its ability.  yes a bit slow shutter speed but after a bit youll figure it out'and get great pictures.  Excelent pictures and even better memories captured.  All in all for less than a $100, piece of mind of not ruining your camera in the rain while riding to your favorite spot in the mountains or on that amazing bike ride!  Surprise trip to Bahamas! Disney water rides!  now remember it is an underwater camera so its a bit bulky but not by much compared to some digital cams out there, I can still put it in my front jean pockets or side cargo pants pocket...  I also use energizer rechargables and shut it off after each shot until ready for the next one, and it will last you a bit, if not go for the super lithium energizer digital ones and you'll get your $10 bucks worth in pictures.  the more you open the back the more risk of getting water in it! (get good batteries!)  I love my camera, as a second camera,  I usually carry it when going to adventure parks, so i dont miss pictures on water rides!!!  if you are still reading, you do want one, Get it! you'll be happy! I've had mine for over 3 yrs!!! with no issues.

Reviews.Title: Good bal
Reviews.Author: Philip Shanteau
Reviews.Content: Good balance of cost and usability.The only draw back is shudder lag and slow exposure speed. I thing the 2 meg picture as the lowest setting is the problem. If it is, a software up-grade to allow 750k picture would give a faster exposure. You have to hold the camera still and motion shots tend to blur. Take two or 3 shots just in case.

Reviews.Title: miss melelani
Reviews.Author: melelani
Reviews.Content: Very glad I had the camera for my vacation.  Main peeve was that the screen shut off after a couple seconds.  Also, you could not see the screen in daylight at all.  Good pictures in shallow water (light) Good for beginner photogs.

Reviews.Title: Difficult Entry
Reviews.Author: WaterBaby
Reviews.Content: Excited to receive product until I tried to open it to install batteries & media card. Frustration abounded 1st with lousy directions and illustrations to open this watertight area. Immediately snapped part of the "access" lever off because instruction illustrated that I should "pull it out" or was it "slide it down".  Anyway, broke lever half off then was able to get the "little tiny black button" next to the lever to push in to release the lever the rest of the way!  Viola!  So, camera can be opened but not without angst.  Got the stuff inserted and reclosed the case which seems to be watertight.  Hopefully the rest of the review as to cameras operation and photography will follow in May after I get to use it. Court is still out....

Reviews.Title: Poor photo quality and problems with connection to computer.
Reviews.Author: texasfamily
Reviews.Content: This falls under the category of you get what you pay for.  The camera did fare well in water, but I noticed a definite lack of quality of the photos I shot with it.  My biggest complaint after taking it on one vacation was an inability to download photos through the port designed to connect to a computer.  It worked a few times, but then went dead.  If I had to do it over again I would not have purchased it.

Reviews.Title: Good camera BAD accessories
Reviews.Author: Photo guy
Reviews.Content: I purchased the Vivitar Vivicam 8400 for a vacation in the West Indies. On my first outing with the camera the strap became disconnected from the camera, and it sank into the sea, never to be recovered. Overall the camera appeared to be a quality point and shoot, it didn't leak at all when in the water, took acceptable pictures above and below the surface, and was easy to use. If you plan on keeping the camera long enough to download your pictures, or if you would like to use it more than once, I do not recommend using the included strap without some modifications to ensure that the latch on the strap will not disconnect abruptly.

Reviews.Title: Don't Buy This Camera!!
Reviews.Author: A. Johns
Reviews.Content: I took this camera with me on a cruise.  My thought was to use it at all of the ports where I knew there would be water.  I was unable to take any good pictures with it.  The camera has a delay that you can't change, so you push the button to take a picture and 2 seconds later it then takes the picture.  Not worth the money at ALL.  I was unable to get ANY pictures and am sending it back for a full refund.  You would be better off spending more money and getting a nicer, more reliable underwater camera.  If I could give zero stars I would have...

Reviews.Title: Terrible camera
Reviews.Author: EC
Reviews.Content: This camera is terrible - you get what you pay for.  This is not a camera for snorkeling.  The screen is basically nonexistent.  You cannot see the pictures on the screen.  The buttons are extremely hard to push.  You never know when you take a picture because the camera does not have a preview feature for immediately after you take the picture.  After only 7 days of using the camera, the latch for the batteries and memory card busted while I was in the water - luckily on the last day of my vacation - but the camera will not function now.If you are snorkeling and want some great pics, check out the Olympus underwater cameras (Stylus Tough series).  They take awesome pictures and have a screen that you can actually see.  It is worth the extra money.

Reviews.Title: Fun waterproof camera
Reviews.Author: lisamdh
Reviews.Content: We were gift this camera before a trip to Mexico.  It was great to be able to have it with us wherever we went without having to worry about water or rain.  Camera takes beautiful underwater pictures although the shutter speed is extremely slow so it's very difficult to capture moving objects (such as fish when snorkeling.)  Also takes decent pictures out of the water as long as you shake any water droplets off of the lens.We had no problems with it leaking and enjoyed the photos that we got from it, but I really wish the shutter speed was faster so we didn't have to miss out all of the great fish pictures from snorkeling.

Reviews.Title: Not Bad for the price you pay
Reviews.Author: Camo Camper
Reviews.Content: I have only owned this camera a few months now but overall I am pleased with its function. I have brought it on two canoe trips (one to Moosehead lake in Maine and the Androscoggin river in Maine, an ocean trip up in Winter Harbor, and have used it when it was pouring outside. Normally I try to baby my gear but with this camera (as it was not that pricey) I have been a little more rough on it. While canoeing down the river we dumped and everything went into the water. The camera did freeze initially that is why I am giving this a 3 star rating rather than any higher...but as soon as I got it home to see if I had lost any of my picture or whether they would come out at all, I was surprised to see that not only had they come out but they were pretty nice pictures (not as nice as my regular camera) but overall good.The only issues I have with this camera is that it does not float and sometimes the lens can fog/ water-fy the picture meaning that it creates a reflect/refraction in the picture...like if you were to drop a water droplet on a print out of a photo and it distorted-kind of.Overall I would say that is worth the 100 bucks if you are just doing small water trips and want a camera that you don't have to develop pics with or worry if it gets banged up.

Reviews.Title: Better than a disposable waterproof camera
Reviews.Author: RRmom
Reviews.Content: I wanted a cheap waterproof camera that I could take with us on vacation.  We were going to an indoor waterpark, so I needed a camera that had a flash (which I could not find in the disposable waterproof ones) and I didn't want to spend a lot of money-just in case it was stolen. I was hesitant to purchase this one after reading the reviews, but I found it at Wal Mart for $80 and decided to give it a try.  Let me start off by saying that the outdoor shots I took turned out pretty decent.  I got a few really good indoor shots, but most of them were somewhat blurry-I do have 2 active kids, so I don't think that helped.  In my opinion, I'd rather have blurry shots than no shots at all.I did take 1 or 2 pictures underwater, but they didn't turn out because my child wouldn't stay under long enough.  The camera did go underwater several times, but only for 30 seconds at a time, so I can't really report on how it does for extended periods of time under water-ie: snorkeling.It did not leak as some other reviews mentioned and it's still working.  I still have the original (disposable) batteries in it and they haven't run down yet-I took approximately 90 pictures in a 2 day period.It does have a 1 or 2 second delay once you hit the button, but you just have to learn that you can't move the camera until the live screen is back up.  This really is not a big deal-I don't think.  Also, don't expect to take rapid photos with this camera.The flash really is not that good, but it's obviously better than not having a flash.Don't expect to use this as an everyday camera-it's a good substitute when you're going to the pool or the waterpark and you want to get pictures without worrying about ruining your good camera or having it stolen.The quality of the pictures is definitely better than a disposable camera, but in no way are they professional quality.The camera is also fairly easy to use.

Reviews.Title: Vivitar vivicam 8400
Reviews.Author: Reid N. Doe
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera for my daughter as she loves to snorkel and take underwater pictures. This was one of the rare cameras at a low price that indicated on the package for use underwater to 30 feet. Seemed perfect for my daughters needs. The camera didn't get a chance to go anywhere underwater as the lense fogged up instantly when it came in contact with a few drops of water at the surface. The rear screen dimmed to the point you couldn't see what you were taking pictures of. She instantly took it out of the water and opened the case which was fully closed and locked only to find the inside of the camera wet. She probably could have done better with a much less expensive camera with a zip lock bag around it.This camera is nothing but junk. If the camera cannot handle water (even a small amount) it shouldn't be sold as an "underwater camera".

Reviews.Title: Do not buy!
Reviews.Author: Amy E. Shadwell
Reviews.Content: Horrible!! Product leaked the very first time I used it!!! Ruined all my pictures! Really put a damper on my vacation!

Reviews.Title: Nothing good to say, sorry
Reviews.Author: Spyder
Reviews.Content: Bought this camera on a whim just before a trip to the Caribbean where we would do a lot of snorkeling.  It comes with a tiny getting started guide which tells you to get full instructions on their web site.  Can't do that from a boat, and unfortunately the buttons and operations are not at all intuitive.  Even worse however, is that the camera failed after 20 pictures.  Water did not leak in, but it stopped showing images on the screen, stopped taking pictures, and oddly, wouldn't turn off.  The screen glowed a dull blank glow with no image, menu items or instructions.  I had to pull the batteries to shut it off, and when I put them back in I got teh same dull glow.  New batteries did nothing.  I was able to download the pictures and a few were OK.  I think with more practice it would be adequate and fun for simple underwater pictures - if it only worked.The packaging said not to return to the seller, but to call Vivitar directly for support.  Haven't done that yet but I rather have my money back than to keep this poor device.

Reviews.Title: Totally inadequate for advertised use.
Reviews.Author: J. Elliott "LibraryJim"
Reviews.Content: I received it yesterday and was surprised at the weight. It's larger and heavier than a regular digital camera, but I guess that's to be expected.However, what I did not like is the long 'lag time' in taking photos. I'm talking about maybe 5 seconds here between pushing the button and the actual picture capture. For a camera designed for sports and nature action, that seems an unacceptably long time. This may be good if one is setting up for a still shot in a damp condition, but for use in a white-water rafting trip or canoeing, this is a 'deal breaker'.  I never could get the 'burst' feature to engage.The second drawback is that while it is advertised as a 'waterproof' camera, the packaging boasts 'water resistant'. NOT the same thing.Third: totally inadequate for night shots.  When using the flash, the recharge time is about the same as  the shutter speed -- about three to five seconds. During that time, the screen goes blank, and the flash ready light (a blue light on the left of the screen) flashes. The flash is only good for about two feet. Everything else is in darkness. There is no scene setting for night or low light photography.I would not recommend this to anyone seeking a camera for outdoor, water related action photography.  And this is a Vivitar, a leading name in cameras! They should recall and re-work their design on this model.

Reviews.Title: OK for the money
Reviews.Author: J. Green
Reviews.Content: This camera is ok for the money, but it is slow in focusing, processing, flash, etc.  Not what you need underwater.  Its much better than a disposable, but not really that good.  For the price, its fine, just realize what you are purchasing.  For $100, there are much better cameras.

Reviews.Title: OK for low end but very slow....
Reviews.Author: T. Gordon
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera to use during snorkling. Overall, the camera is very sturdy and has a very solid feel.The pictures I took were nice even with the challemges of using this camera.1)Display is almost impossible to see when underwater and in most lighting conditions.2)Default setting shuts the camera off after a minute or so, I could not get the system to retain changed settings for auto shutdown once the camera was turned off.3)There is a 1~3 second lag from the time the shutter button is pushed and when the picture was actually taken.4) Flash is weak.5) You must use the USB cable to pull the pictures from the camera as SD card formatted by this camera is not recognized on multiple PC's.While snorkling, It was very difficult to frame shots as I could not see the screen. I resorted to taking as many photos as I could in hopes of getting a few good ones as I could not see what was in the frame.I had to turn the camera back on several times.It was a pain having to focus on keeping the camera on instead of enjoying what I was doing.The lag time was killing me. I had tested the system before going on the trip with a standard SD card. Once I saw the lag, I tested a SanDisk Extreme III card from my SLR which is quite a bit faster when used with a Digital SLR. In this camera, it made no difference. I missed several good shots due to the lag.Once I got home, I was supprised that I could not pull the photos directly from the memory card and I had to use the USB connector.Overall, this is an OK underwater camera for less than $90. On my next trip, I plan on purchasing a higher end camera that is more usable or I will purchase an underwater case for one of my other Point & Shoot cameras.

Reviews.Title: Not happy with the camera
Reviews.Author: Bruce Sarnowitz "Sammydogg"
Reviews.Content: Bought it, took underwater pictures. I could not see the screen while underwater and did not know if the camera was on or off. Very frustrating! The camera has a delay when snapping the pic, got some smudged images because I was moving while the camera was thinking about taking the pics. Got home from vacation and returned it. I did not experience a leaky camera because I used an o-ring lubricant to properly seal the camera from water. I would suggest the same to anyone who buys this camera. I would think that Vivitar would make a better product than this.

Reviews.Title: Fairly good underwater camera
Reviews.Author: Daniel V. Meyer
Reviews.Content: I used the Vivitar underwater camera on a recent trip to Yucatan. We snoreled in the Caribbean and in cenotes (underwater caves). The good stuff - it was airtight, the shutter is big and easy to use, some pictures came out just fine, the price is quite reasonable. The not-so-good stuff - most pictures weren't worth it, focusing is guesswork because you can't see the screen, with no optical zoom you need to get quite close (fish were gone before I could get the picture). The flash helped though I found it difficult to use. I imagine a camera costing $500 would work better. But for a camera costing less than $100, I got a few fine pictures and had fun trying to "shoot" fish before they swam away.

Reviews.Title: Works but not well!
Reviews.Author: Kenneth Greenstein
Reviews.Content: Has so far been waterproof so far, but is slow in taking pictures and hard to see what is taken when you are underwater and the sunlight is behind you.  Maybe I'm spoiled but I prefer a camera with a viewfinder and have not been able to find one that is waterproof, under several hundred dollars, and not too bulky to snorkle with. My pictures were just OK, nothing to brag about, and the flash did not help underwater.

Reviews.Title: Underwater camera
Reviews.Author: Lois "editor"
Reviews.Content: A great buy and bargain ! I compared and contrasted the two cameras. The review for the Vivitar made me purchase it and I do not regret it.  It takes AA batteries which can be purchased anywhere. Water proof up to 30 feet and the seals are tight . The only thing it doesn't have is sound for above ground video---But for the price it is awesome and I purchase the floating strap as well!! Great screen resolution too!!!

Reviews.Title: broke on second use
Reviews.Author: C. Hunt
Reviews.Content: this camera fried underwater on its second use. water got inside camera and made it unusable. i stayed within the 10 ft range in the ocean and it still broke. piece of crap!

Reviews.Title: Vivitar 8400 Camera
Reviews.Author: Robert D. Slavik "rockyarddog"
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera in hopes of getting some great underwater pictures of my trip to the Bahama's.  After taking a large number of pic's,  I began to review the underwater shots of a beautful diving day.  Upon review,  I would say that only abot 25% 0f them were worth saving.  Most were blurry, but that is to be expected.  Not all shots come out clear.  However,  I was never able to get the flash to work even upon calling customer service.  The camera has been sent back for repair or replacement.  I will hold out my final opinion after seeing how this all pans out! RS

Reviews.Title: COMPLETE P.O.S.
Reviews.Author: Jason
Reviews.Content: My girlfriend finally got the chance to use this camera a year after I got it for her. She turned it on once after putting brand new batteries in it and customized the settings. The next time we went to turn it on the screen went white and now it doesn't work at ALL. It self destructed before being used even once!!!!!! I've emailed VIVITAR so they can take responsibility for their crappy camera, I even brought up my warranty, and they didn't even respond to my email. So now i'm stuck with a useless camera that I will probably end up using as target practice. Don't waste your money like I did.

Reviews.Title: Vivitar Digitial Waterproof camera
Reviews.Author: S. Klein
Reviews.Content: This camera was bought for my wife as a spur of the moment 11th anniversary present.  She loves it.  Though she did not use it in the pool for 3 months because of bad reviews. At first she only used it on dry land as a point and shoot camera. When she finally used it at the pool she loved the photos and so did the kids.Then, last week she jumped quickly in the pool and flooded the camera.  We noted the battery door had come open.  She claims user error.  Being in a hurry to jump in the water.  (Jumping in the water and most water proof cameras advise against diving into the water.)  Plus she thinks the camera battery door might have bumped directly when she jumped in.She was very unhappy so she bought a 25 dollar waterproof camera (actually a camera that comes in a case) and I bought her a replacement FujiFilm XP from the store.  We were able to take these ones on our vacation to St. Augustine.  However, Neither of them meet her expectations.  (Though the Fuji does have sound with it's videos.)My wife returned from our vacation this morning and grabbed her old vivitar putting in batteries and a sd card.  She booted it up and discovered.  Yes, After letting it sit and dry out.  The camera does boot up.The LCD screen is a bit messed up and the FLASH no longer works.It still takes photos and she now wants to take it back to the pool to try to capture some underwater moments with her vivitar that took a flooding and kept working.BTW  No it did not ruin our 4GB SD card.  Yes It was very flooded.  I noticed that it was flooded because I had been underwater looking at her and saw water in the lenses area when she was looking to boot up and take my photo.Yes, I will post photos when I can that are taken with my wife's camera and her permission.This has turned out to be a good gift and spur of the moment buy.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: CRose
Reviews.Content: This camera is great for the money.  There is about a one second delay, but I found that it wasn't that big of a problem.  Once printed, the pictures were even better than we expected. The color quality is great, the zoom feature works great, and it's lights and easy to carry.

Reviews.Title: Vivitar Under water camera
Reviews.Author: Richard D. Alderson
Reviews.Content: The price for this camera was the only thing about this camera that was worth anything.  The Camera came without a manual and is not the most easiest camera to operate under water much less on land.  I requested a manual from the seller and never received one.  The previous reviews on this camera said that the pictures came out very nice but I beg to differ with those reviews.  I thought that the pictures were not very clear at all.  Half of the time the flash did not work so those pictures were worthless.  When the flash did work the picture was grainy at best.  The camera also ate through batteries very quickly.  During a 45 minute dive the batteries did not last even though they were new batteries.  Do not waiste your money on this camera.

Reviews.Title: No Audio for Video Feature
Reviews.Author: skip
Reviews.Content: I researched many camera models that would suit my purpose for fishing trip photography and settled on the Vivitar 8400 8.1 MP Underwater Camera. It seems superbly made and I like the way it feels in my hands, the button layout and operation is exceptional. Photos are great and video quality is satisfactory for my purposes with one big exception - there is NO MIC and NO AUDIO!!! I am very disappointed and would like to return the camera. No matter how it looks and feels, it does not meet my needs.

Reviews.Title: Worst Present Ever
Reviews.Author: Peter O'kelly
Reviews.Content: This is the absolute worst camera in the world. I HATE IT! If you are someone who loves cameras, this is a death row sentence camera. If you want someone to cry because of how awful the picture quality is, buy this.  If you want to be disappointed, buy this. If you want to throw a camera away, buy this.

Reviews.Title: takes getting used to
Reviews.Author: pickngrin
Reviews.Content: Just bought this for a trip to a waterpark. Played with it in our pool to test it out. We had lots of fun with it, only got a few good shots because it is hard to see the LCD screen underwater. Pictures are actually pretty clear. I am actually a trained photographer so I am not used to point and shoot small cameras, but this one is actually pretty fun.Downside is that it takes regular AA batteries which I am sure will need replacing after only one day of shooting.

Reviews.Title: VivCam
Reviews.Author: pbduck
Reviews.Content: I cannot give a review I had to return the itemno problems with it I never opened it.I ordered the wrong thing!

2.4 inch TFT LCD screen
Movie mode. Digital Video resolutions (without sound)  640x480 (VGA), 320x240( QVGA).
64MB Internal Flash memory, and supports SD Card memory compatible up to 8GB.
8x Digital Zoom
